Posts.Content: Jun 11, 2010 07:17PM - edited Jun 11, 2010 07:19PM by swanseagirl Hi Debbie, Wow, it sure is confusing.  Met with surgeon and went through pathology with fine tooth comb. He had already talked with an onc and radiologist and had researched other options before I saw him. He said text book decision would be axillary dissection.  However, he had spoken with both onc and rads and we are going to do chemo then rads on breast (had lumpectomy) and nodes.  If something further down the line reoccurs, an axillary dissection will have to happen. I was relieved that my surgeon had researched and talked with fellow professionals instead of throwing the  one option at me. I am still scared to death of what the future holds and I am looking at my glass as half full and with chemo and rads it will become a hell of a lot fuller. I have to hold onto to the fact these are professionals and they know what they are doing.  I meet with onc and radiologist next week. Even saying that, i had a huge meltdown last night.  All the desicion making is overwhelming. Do you ever get to the point where you can breatha and say this is going to be OK? Thanks, Jules
Posts.Title: Please help I need advice swanseagirl debbie6122

Does anyone have any advice on what to ask the surgeon.  Should I get my nodes taken out. Please help! Dx 5/10/2010, ILC, 1cm, Stage IIA, Grade 1, 1/3 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 29, 2011 01:01AM - edited Jan 29, 2011 01:02AM by swanseagirl Hi LAdies, I had my last round of chemo coktails the end of October, 2010.  My hair is growing back slowly. I have enough to get bed hair but not enough to go outside without my wig.  If I'm walking I wear a base ball hat. Before that a scarf and baseball.  I love my wig and it gives me the confidence I need when I am around professionals. My eyebrows are growing at a snails rate. I can finally see eye lahses, blonde, but they are there. Hang in there xxxx Jules

Posts.Content: May 25, 2010 09:46PM swanseagirl wrote: Stacy, I was diagnosed May 13th and i am having a lumpectomy June 2nd. Everything is scary.  From the first time you hear you have cancer to the word chemo.  I'm new at this so i do not have words of wisdom, but I do have words of support. You must be a strong women to be raising twins with autism on your own.  You can be strong with this.  I'm still getting to the strong part. There are so many wonderful women on this site.  They will become your supporters.  I am scared of having surgery but in my heart i am more concerned about teh chemo.  I think it's the vanity side of it.  Keep in mind sufgery will get  the cancer out and chemo will keep your future strong. I send you and your twins hugs.

Posts.Content: May 26, 2010 08:49AM swanseagirl wrote: Jenny, thanks for the hugs.  I didn't realise that when you join this club (bc) you instantly meet so many wonderful people who care.  I am slowly (very slowly) coming out of my doom and gloom, feel sorry for myself. Hearing everyones stories I'm realising I can do this.  It will be a hard journey, but, with the help of people like you and the kind words, I am not going to go through this alone.  i hope you are doing well in your treatment. Hugs right back at you!!!!!
Posts.Title: Scared and feeling lonely swanseagirl swanseagirl

Posts.Content: Aug 18, 2010 06:43PM swanseagirl wrote: Hi everyone. first time posting on this thread. I was dx'd in May. Surgery June 2nd (lumpectomy) started chemo July 15th, rads start sometime in November.  I didn't have the oncotype test as I have 1 node involvement and didn't want to spend the money.  I knew I had to do chemo and rads to get full benefits. For those of you that are scared of chemo, please do not be.  I will be having my third next week. Hallf way there.  Is it enjoyable, no, is it doable yes.  For me it has been more than doable. We all have to make personal choices, but don't base not having chemo becasue you are afraid. There are so many wonder gals on this site you will abd can, including myself, help you get through the chemo. Hugs to all xxxxxx

Hugs Chey, congrats on your MRI results!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! Hugs
